Name.BusinessNameLine1: PUTNAM MUSEUM OF HISTORY AND NATURAL SCIENCE

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: THE PUTNAM MUSEUM INSPIRES IDEAS, DIALOGUE AND INTERACTION AMONG PEOPLE OF ALL AGES THROUGH ENTERTAINING EXPERIENCES THAT CONNECT THEM TO HISTORY, CULTURES, NATURE AND THE ENVIRONMENT; BY PRESERVING COLLECTIONS; AND BY PRESENTING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, IMAX FILMS, AND EXHIBITS.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE PUTNAM MUSEUM INSPIRES IDEAS, DIALOGUE AND INTERACTION AMONG PEOPLE OF ALL AGES THROUGH ENTERTAINING EXPERIENCES THAT CONNECT THEM TO HISTORY, CULTURES, NATURE AND THE ENVIRONMENT; BY PRESERVING COLLECTIONS; AND BY PRESENTING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, IMAX FILMS, AND EXHIBITS.
IRS990.Description: IMAX THEATRE: The Museum's IMAX Theatre offers educational and topical films and presentations. Examples include Australia: Land Beyond Time, Hubble 3D, Under the Sea 3D, and Wild Ocean 3D. The films and presentations allow viewers to see nature in all its glory, to learn about history and other cultures, and to travel to all parts of the world.In an era when environmental awareness is part of the daily conversation and cultures across the globe are increasingly interacting via technology and their economies, IMAX films that enlighten and educate the public about a variety of environments and cultures are significant to our current and future ability to co-exist productively.

Activity2.Description: EXHIBITS AND EDUCATION: The Museum offers permanent and changing interactive, immersive exhibits and hands-on educational programs related to history, cultures, nature, and environments. Examples include GPS Adventures, Ocean Voyagers, Davenport's Civil Rights Movement, Ancient Egypt, and Our Region and the Civil War. Interaction with actual artifacts and educators in "character" provide dynamic learning experiences and real connections that cannot be obtained from textbooks or the internet. These experiences stimulate the desire for more knowledge and exploration.

Activity3.Description: VISITOR SERVICES: Between the IMAX Theatre, Exhibits and Educational Programs, the Museum hosted more than 165,000 people this year. Customer service staff and amenities located in the Museum's grand lobby space support and enhance the overall visitor experience.

ActivityOther.Description: COLLECTIONS AND CURATORIAL SERVICES: An important part of the Museum's mission is the preservation of the community's history. The Museum houses approximately 170,000 items in its permanent collection. These items are expertly cared for, are available for research purposes, and many become part of permanent and temporary exhibits or are used to enhance educational programs.MEMBERSHIP SERVICES: The Museum has approximately 3,800 memberships ranging from individuals to families to businesses. These memberships encompass over 12,000 people. Members enjoy special benefits such as the first glimpse of a new film or exhibit.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Museum owns a significant collection of science, history and art objects that are not capitalized in the statements of financial position. The Museum utilizes its collections for public benefit through education, exhibit and research activities. Appropriate environmental conditions and staff are provided for the proper care and management of collections in both exhibit and storage areas. Purchased collection items are recorded as decreases in unrestricted net assets in the year in which the items are acquired, or in temporarily or permanently restricted net assets if the assets used to purchase the items are restricted by donors; contributed collection items are excluded from the financial statements. Proceeds from deaccessions or insurance recoveries are reflected as non-operating revenue and as increases in the appropriate net asset classes. All works of art, historical treasures and library collections are held for public exhibition, education, or research; are protected, kept unencumbered, cared for, and preserved; and are subject to strict organizational policies governing their use. The value of the Museum's permanent collection is not subject to reasonable estimation.

The Museum collects objects and natural science specimens to preserve the region's natural and human history and provide educational and enriching experiences through interpretive exhibits and museum programming. The collections provide insight into the past, present and future experiences of the people it serves. The Museum's collection is organized into the broad categories of Natural Science, Regional History, Anthropology and Archives.
COSTS OF GOODS SOLD EXPENSE: 138140. RENTAL EXPENSE: 21887.
COSTS OF GOODS SOLD EXPENSE: 138140. RENTAL EXPENSE: 21887. DEACCESSION EXPENSE: 304.

PART X, LINE 2: The Museum has received notification that it qualifies as a tax-exempt organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and a similar section of the state statues and, accordingly, is not subject to federal or state income taxes except on any unrelated business net income the museum may have. The Museum evaluates the tax benefits of a tax position using the more likely than not threshold. As of June 30, 2010, management is not aware of any uncertain tax positions and related tax benefits which would be material to the Museums financial statements. The Museum files U.S. Federal tax returns which for years subsequent to 2006 are subject to examination by taxing authorities.

FundraiserActivityInformation.Activity: CONSULTS ON SUSTAINABLE FUNDRAISING FROM INDIVIDUAL DONORS

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The Museum owns a significant collection of science, history and art objects that are not capitalized in the statements of financial position. The Museum utilizes its collections for public benefit through education, exhibit and research activities. Appropriate environmental conditions and staff are provided for the proper care and management of collections in both exhibit and storage areas. Purchased collection items are recorded as decreases in unrestricted net assets in the year in which the items are acquired, or in temporarily or permanently restricted net assets if the assets used to purchase the items are restricted by donors; contributed collection items are excluded from the financial statements. Proceeds from deaccessions or insurance recoveries are reflected as non-operating revenue and as increases in the appropriate net asset classes. All works of art, historical treasures and library collections are held for public exhibition, education, or research; are protected, kept unencumbered, cared for, and preserved; and are subject to strict organizational policies governing their use. The value of the Museum's permanent collection is not subject to reasonable estimation.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Director Joyce Bawden and Director Mark Bawden have a family relationship. Director Diane Puthoff and Director Dana Waterman are both partners at the same law firm.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A DRAFT OF THE MUSEUM'S RETURN IS PROVIDED TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. THEY ARE ASKED TO REVIEW IT AND DIRECT QUESTIONS TO THE BOARD CHAIRMAN. ANY NESSECARY CHANGES ARE MADE, AND A FINAL VERSION IS SENT TO ALL BOARD MEMBERS.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Upon election to the Board of Trustees, members receive a copy of the Museum's Conflict of Interest Policy. The policy requires each board member to disclose actual or potential conflicts of interest and annually reaffirm his or her understanding of the policy and agreement to comply with it. This annual affirmation is documented through a Conflict of Interest Disclosure form.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Key employees of the Museum are the CEO and CFO. The process for setting the salary of the CEO rests with the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees. The committee reviews the CEO's compensation annually, keeping written records of its review, which includes comparison of the CEO's salary to that of similar organizations. The CEO determines the salary of the CFO in the same manner. All full time employees of the Museum are offered the same optional benefits package that includes partial funded health insurance and a matching contribution to a retirement plan.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE MUSEUM MAKES ITS GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY, AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AVAILABLE TO MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: OTHER GROSS AMOUNT FROM SALES OF ASSETS OTHER THAN INVENTORY:
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: On March 22, 2010, the Museum entered into a facilities agreement with the City of Davenport and the Davenport Community School District whereby the Museum transferred a fully depreciated building to the City in consideration for $995,000. Under the terms of the agreement, the City is required to pay the Museum in three installments as follows: $450,000 by May 6, 2010, $300,000 on July 1, 2011 and $245,000 on July 1, 2012. The Museum received the first installment of $450,000 in July, 2010. The Museum recognized a gain of $995,000 in 2010 in connection with the transfer of the building.

Form990ScheduleRPartII.PrimaryActivities: SUPPORT AND FUNDING OF PUTNAM MUSUEM
